The BlipBox has a number of operating modes, each providing a different set of functionality.

section.title: Playing Notes
section.para: The cross mode lets you play notes on a software instrument by pressing points on the touch screen. A straight cross follows your finger to indicate the current position. Any MIDI or OSC enabled instrument can be played this way. Used this way, the BlipBox could be compared to having a Kaossilator connected to your computer. With lots of nice bright lights.

The box also allows simultaneous control of a couple of parameters that can be mapped to your instrument or filters. One parameter can be adjusted by sliding your finger along a column of LED's (i.e. vertically), another by tweaking the side-mounted knob.
A simple setup lets you choose the musical scale and base note that the surface maps to. Setup mode is accessed by a double click on the side button - i.e. pressing it twice in quick succession.

section.title: Manipulating Sounds
section.para: By pressing the button on the side once, you enter criss mode. Well we had to call it something. It is recognised by a diagonal, as oppposed to a straight, cross.

In this mode, the box is a configurable x/y control surface, meaning that your finger's position on the screen can be translated to any number of software parameters. The position is sensed with 10 bits precision, allowing much finer control than most MIDI controllers. Parameter outputs and ranges can be set as you want them - inversed, amplified or attenuated.

section.title: Hold It
section.para: So the button on the side is used to switch back and forth between cross and criss modes. Furthermore, if you press it while using the touch screen, the current position will be held and indicated with a single dot. To release it, the button is pressed again.

This means that when in cross mode, by holding a note down and pressing the button, you will be put into criss mode while the current note is still playing. To stop the racket, press the button again.

section.title: Fader Box
section.para: Another function the BlipBox will serve with gusto is as a straightforward fader box. It provides up to 10 faders which are adjusted by simply pressing or sliding the indicator to the level you want. The LED's indicate the current position of each fader. Each virtual fader's range can be set individually if so desired, making use of the 10-bit resolution that the touch screen provides.
Note that since the touch screen is not multi-touch, you can only adjust one virtual fader at a time.

section.title: Monome Emulation
section.para: The box can also emulate a monome. The only restriction, apart from the size, is that only one button can be pressed at one time. The lack of tactile feedback will be missed by some, while others may enjoy sliding their fingers across the smooth touch screen.

In addition to an 8x8 grid of virtual buttons, the BlipBox as a monome provides three analog inputs. Each extra column of LED's on each side can be used as a virtual fader, the third input is provided by the knob on the side.
